## Racializaton Definiton

Racialization is the level to which the public and elite language used to describe an institution and its actions evoke race and thus make relevant and highlight debates around racial inequality or racial resentments.

## {data-background-image="figs/NYT_Words_Disappear.jpg" data-background-size="contain" data-background-position="center" data-background-opacity="1"}

## Research Questions

- Which agencies are more racialized than others?  
  - How has that changed over time?  
  - How does that vary across different contexts?  

    - e.g. policy documents, media coverage, and
advocacy reports
    
- How do perceptions of racialization vary between agencies perceived as conservative versus liberal?

## Contribution  
<!-- the why -->  

- We develop a new measure of racialization.  
- We find that ideology and racialization are distinct.  
- This measure helps us study:  
  - When institutional rhetoric deviates from agency actions  
  - Institutional legitimacy  
  - The relationship between racialization and policy implementation  



## {#Concepts}
 
<!--incremental on box -->

::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="33%" .column data-incremental="true"}
### Perceived Ideology
<div style="border: 2px solid #2196F3; padding: 30px; margin-bottom: 30px; border-radius: 10px; font-size: 18px;" data-incremental="true">
Percieved liberal-conservative:

Expert surveys, appointments, donations, and voting patterns 
  <br>
  <span style="font-style: italic; font-size: 12px; color: #333;">(Clinton and Lewis (2008); Richardson, et al. (2019); Richardson, et al. (2024); Epstein (1999); Nixon (2004); Chen and Johnson (2014); Maranto (2005); Maranto and Hult (2004); Bertelli and Grose (2011))</span>
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="33%" .column data-incremental="true"}
### Race & the Bureaucracy
<div style="border: 2px solid #2196F3; padding: 30px; margin-bottom: 30px; border-radius: 10px; font-size: 18px;" data-incremental="true">
- Historical exclusion and segregation have shaped public and elite perceptions of their ideological leanings. As polarization intensifies, racialized rhetoric influences how agencies are seen as liberal or conservative. Understanding these perceptions requires disentangling racialization from traditional ideology measures.
  <br>
  <span style="font-style: italic; font-size: 12px; color: #333;">(King (1999); Choi and Rainey (2010); Schickler (2016); Tate (2003); White and Laird (2020); Mansbridge (1999); Watkins-Hayes (2009); Minta (2009); Juenke and Preuhs (2012); Hayes and Hibbing (2017))</span>
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="33%" .column data-incremental="true"}
### Race & Policy Framing
<div style="border: 2px solid #2196F3; padding: 30px; margin-bottom: 30px; border-radius: 10px; font-size: 18px;" data-incremental="true">
- Racial attitudes are deeply intertwined with policy preferences and partisan polarization, contributing to how agency policies are strategically framed by elites and the public. Recognizing the role of race moves us beyond conventional ideology scales and reveals how agencies function as racialized actors within the policymaking process.
  <br>
  <span style="font-style: italic; font-size: 12px; color: #333;">(Gilens, 1999); Kellstedt (2003); Hutchings & Valentino (2004); Bartels, 2020; Stephens-Dougan, L. (2020); O’Brian (2024)</span>
</div>
:::

:::

## Key Takeaways

- Racialization varies over time, despite stable core missions.
<!-- - Framing processes at work recast missions to emphasize race and inequality.-->
- Racialization is tied to perceived ideological extremism, perhaps perceptions of neutrality.
- Perceived "Centrist" agencies received less racialized attention.
